name: HX-10
keyboard: QWERTY mechanical keyboard73 keys with graphic symbols and accentuated letters through keys combinations
graphics: Mode 2 : 256 x 192 with 16 colors (Hires mode)Mode 3 : 64 x 48 with 16 colors (Multi colour mode)32 sprites
sound: General Instruments AY-3-8910 Programmable Sound Generator3 channels, 8 octaves
ports: 2 joystick sockets1 cardridge slotTape-recorder plug (1200/2400 bauds)Composite video outputCentronics interfaceRF video output1 expansion bus
description:
The HX-10 was a classic MSX 1 computer with no special feature... But it was one of the first MSX computers to be exported outside Japan. It met a good success in UK where it can still be found in flea markets and boot sales...

Apparently there were several models of the HX-10 (D, DP, DPN, F, E and S) depending on the country they were sold, but it's not clear what's the difference between them so far... The HX-10 DPN and F had a Scart video output instead of RF/composite outputs, and the HX-10S had only 16 kb RAM.

In its native country, the HX-10 was also named Pasopia IQ to fit in the Pasopia family developped by Toshiba.

shot.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> LEFT & RIGHT SIDES</strong></font><br><blockquote>Power switch on the left side, 2 joystick and printer connectors on the right side.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> CONNECTORS</strong></font><br><blockquote>From left to right:<br> • Two joystick connectors<br> • Parallel printer connector<br> • Expansion bus connector, mainly used for the floppy drive unit<br> • Composite video output<br> • Audio output<br> • RF Aerial output<br> • Tape recorder DIN socket with remote control </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> OPENED</strong></font><br><blockquote>The keyboard was made by Alps, a big Japanese keyboards manufacturer.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> MAINBOARD</strong></font><br><blockquote><b><font color="blue">(1)</font></b> Power transformer and regulation components<br> <b><font color="blue">(2)</font></b> Anonymous video chip, actually a TI 9929, compatible with the 9918 standard MSX video chip<br> <b><font color="blue">(3)</font></b> RF aerial modulator<br> <b><font color="blue">(4)</font></b> 32 KB ROM chip containing the Microsoft BASIC and I/O routines<br> <b><font color="blue">(5)</font></b> Tape recorder remote control relay<br> <b><font color="blue">(6)</font></b> ROM Cartridges slot<br> <b><font color="blue">(7)</font></b> Z80A processor, here a Sharp version<br> <b><font color="blue">(8)</font></b> Custom Toshiba I/O chip, replaces the standard I/O plus several standard 74xx chips<br> <b><font color="blue">(9)</font></b> Keyboard connectors<br> <b><font color="blue">(10)</font></b> General Instruments AY-8910 sound generator<br> <b><font color="blue">(11)</font></b> 8 x 8264 chips hold the 64 KB of main RAM<br> <b><font color="blue">(12)</font></b> 8 x 4116 chips hold the 16 KB video RAM<br> <b><font color="blue">(13)</font></b> Video circuitry which provides the composite signal </blockquote>

advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT </strong></font><br><blockquote>advert said<br><br><font color="#666666"> ...If you want a computer that won't be obsolete in a few years, buy an MSX.<br> If you want one of the best-selling MSX computers in Japan, buy a Toshiba HX10.</font></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE ADVERT #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>This is an advertisement for the HX-10D. If you can read japanese maybe you could tell us what's the difference with a HX-10...</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE ADVERT. #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>The Pasopia IQ seems to be the name of the HX-10 in its native country.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE ADVERT. #3</strong></font><br><blockquote>I love this advert ! Their pullovers are so... colored.</blockquote>

MEGA RAM DISK 256|||from DDX (Brazil)|||<br><font color="red"><strong>> MEGA RAM DISK 256</strong></font><br><strong>> from DDX (Brazil)</strong><br><blockquote>This is the famous Megaram cartridge made in Brzail, used to play all Konami cracked Megarom games.6401999243</blockquote>

Panasonic  FS-IFA1 & FW-RSU1W|||Scanner/Printer interface|||<br><font color="red"><strong>> PANASONIC  FS-IFA1 & FW-RSU1W</strong></font><br><strong>> Scanner/Printer interface</strong><br><blockquote>The FS-IFA1 is the printer/scanner interface (left on the picture) and the FW-RSU1W is the handheld scanner (right on the picture). These expansions are for MSX2 systems.</blockquote>
Sony HBI-232|||RS232c cartridge|||<br><font color="red"><strong>> SONY HBI-232</strong></font><br><strong>> RS232c cartridge</strong><br><blockquote>Used to connect serial printers.</blockquote>

Yamaha mouse #1||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>> YAMAHA MOUSE #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>This mouse was compatible with all MSX systems. It connects to the first Joystick port.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>www.zonadepruebas.com</b></p></blockquote>
Yamaha mouse #2||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>> YAMAHA MOUSE #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>Brand new!<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>www.zonadepruebas.com</b></p></blockquote>

Philips VW0020|||80-col dot-matrix printer|||<br><font color="red"><strong>> PHILIPS VW0020</strong></font><br><strong>> 80-col dot-matrix printer</strong><br><blockquote>This printer was a rebadged version of the Seikosha GP-500.<br>  It was a 80-column, 50 CPS model with a 7x5 dot matrix head.<br>  Commodore and Atari used same hardware basis for their MPS-801 and 1029 printers. </blockquote>

Sanyo DR-202||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>> SANYO DR-202</strong></font><br><blockquote>The ADSS system allowed to quickly search a specific program in a cassette tape and load it. Seach time for a C60 cassette was less than 1 minute.</blockquote>

Bit-corder||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>> BIT-CORDER</strong></font><br><blockquote>Cassete recorder dedicated to Hit-Bit MSX systems, though it could be used with any home computers.</blockquote>

emulator.description: This new MSX emulator can reproduce, among many other MSX, MSX2and  MSX2+ machines, both Panasonic Turbo-R models. Be sure to get the catapult frontend and the system roms from FUNET.
